column3: question
column4: answer

column3: Can I apply for living allowance only under the Study Loan if my tuition fees are covered by a scholarship?
column4: Yes, you may apply for a living allowance under the SL if your scholarship does not provide any allowance.

column3: Do Tuition Fee Loan and Study Loan cover hostel fees?
column4: No, TFL and SL do not cover hostel fees.

column3: Can I mail the Tuition Fee Loan application documents to DBS Singapore?
column4: No, international students with a non-resident guarantor must submit documents in person to DBS Singapore.

column3: What are the criteria to be a Guarantor for TFL and SL?
column4: Guarantors must be aged 21-60, not bankrupt, and meet nationality requirements based on the applicant's status.

column3: Is there an application fee for SUTD?
column4: Yes, a non-refundable application fee of S$20 is required.

column3: Can I accept more than one financial aid award?
column4: Yes, students may be awarded multiple financial aid awards based on their financial situation.

column3: When will I know the results for my financial aid application made during Admission?
column4: You will receive your interim financial aid offer via email after a successful admission outcome and complete application.

column3: Is financial aid available for International Students?
column4: Financial aid for International Students is limited; they may apply for TFL and SL.

column3: What should I submit for my personal portfolio?
column4: Your personal portfolio should showcase relevant attributes and accomplishments in your interest areas, such as external courses, competitions, or personal achievements.

column3: Is it compulsory to stay in the student hostel?
column4: Yes, Freshmores are required to reside at the hostel during Terms 1 and 2 as part of the SUTD experience.

column3: What if I had applied for financing schemes but then receive financial aid awards?
column4: Your financial aid awards will apply first, followed by any financing schemes you applied for, such as PSEA or loans.

column3: Can I apply again if I was not successful in my previous application?
column4: Yes, you can re-apply without penalty, but it's recommended to supplement your application with new relevant information.

column3: What is the minimum IB score for admissions?
column4: There is no minimum IB score requirement; SUTD conducts a comprehensive review of applications considering all attributes.

column3: Is submission of SAT or IELTS scores compulsory for admission?
column4: Yes, submission of either SAT or IELTS scores is compulsory for applicants whose qualifications are not in English.

column3: Are all diplomas accepted for admission?
column4: Generally, diplomas from relevant fields like Engineering or IT are favored, but other diplomas may be considered case-by-case.

column3: Do I need to authorise the IBO to release my IB transcript?
column4: Yes, you must authorize the IBO to release your IB transcripts to SUTD.

column3: When do I start repaying my loan under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
column4: Repayment starts one year after graduation or upon leaving the course, whichever is earlier, with a maximum repayment period of 12 years.

column3: Are testimonials compulsory for application?
column4: Yes, applicants must upload one testimonial or provide referee details in the online application form, ideally from someone who knows them well.

column3: What if I fail Project Work (PW)?
column4: From AY2026, all applicants must present a Pass grade in PW to be eligible for admission; failing PW may require retaking it.

column3: Is it necessary to take Physics major at Year 6 for admission?
column4: No, it is not necessary to undertake Physics major at Year 6 for admission; other Sciences are also considered.

column3: How are students assessed at SUTD?
column4: Students are assessed through a combination of homework, projects, participation, quizzes, mid-terms, and final exams, graded on a GPA of 5.0.

column3: Can I still gain admission if I fail General Paper?
column4: Yes, you may apply even if you did not pass General Paper; other GCE A-Level subjects and non-academic credentials will be considered.

column3: What is the minimum CAP score for admissions?
column4: There is no minimum CAP score requirement; SUTD evaluates applications comprehensively, considering academic and personal attributes.

column3: Can I apply for living allowance only under the Study Loan if my tuition fees are fully covered by a scholarship?
column4: Yes, you may apply for a living allowance under the SL if your scholarship does not provide any allowance.

column3: Do Tuition Fee Loan and Study Loan cover Compulsory Miscellaneous Fees and hostel fees?
column4: TFL and SL do not cover CMF and hostel fees, but students may apply for a living allowance under the SL.

column3: What are the criteria to be a Guarantor for Tuition Fee Loan and Study Loan?
column4: Guarantors must be 21-60 years old, not bankrupt, and can be SC, SPR, or any nationality for IS applicants.

column3: How do I apply for the SUTD Community Grant?
column4: Students do not need to apply; eligible students will be notified via email.

column3: Will I be eligible for SUTD admission if I fail Project Work?
column4: From AY2026, a Pass in Project Work is required for admission for local GCE A-Level applicants.

column3: What if I had not been successful in my application for special programmes?
column4: You will still be considered for single degree programmes and will not be disadvantaged.

column3: What are the criteria to be a Guarantor for both Tuition Fee Loan and Study Loan?
column4: Your Guarantor must be 21-60 years old, not an undischarged bankrupt, and meet specific nationality requirements based on the applicant's status.

column3: Do Tuition Fee Loan and Study Loan cover compulsory miscellaneous fees and hostel fees?
column4: TFL and SL do not cover compulsory miscellaneous fees and hostel fees.

column3: What is the focus of the SUTD undergraduate curriculum?
column4: The SUTD undergraduate curriculum focuses on Design·AI and technology, emphasizing a human-centered design approach.

column3: What are the three main building blocks of education at SUTD?
column4: The three main building blocks are the mandatory core curriculum, variable curriculum, and outside-the-classroom experiences.

column3: What is the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: The Freshmore curriculum equips students with foundational skills and knowledge during the first three terms at SUTD.

column3: How many undergraduate programmes does SUTD offer?
column4: SUTD offers five undergraduate programmes, including Architecture and Sustainable Design, Engineering Product Development, and Design and Artificial Intelligence.

column3: What is the purpose of the Capstone project?
column4: The Capstone project allows students to collaborate across different programmes to tackle real-world challenges in their final year.

column3: What opportunities are available outside the classroom at SUTD?
column4: Outside the classroom, students can engage in internships, research, co-curricular activities, and global exposure opportunities.

column3: What grading system is used in the first term at SUTD?
column4: In the first term, all subjects are grade-free, with students receiving either a 'Pass' or 'No Record' grade.

column3: What is the goal of the variable curriculum at SUTD?
column4: The variable curriculum aims to customize education to suit individual student interests through minors and specialisation tracks.

column3: What is the Freshmore curriculum at SUTD?
column4: Freshmore marks the start of every SUTD journey, equipping students with strong foundations and skills to thrive at the world’s first Design·AI university.

column3: What does the variable curriculum at SUTD allow students to do?
column4: The variable curriculum allows students to customize their education by choosing minors, specialisation tracks, and sector-focused opportunities.

column3: What is the grading system used in the first term at SUTD?
column4: In Term 1, all subjects are grade-free, with students receiving either a 'Pass' or 'No Record' grade.

column3: What is the Freshmore term?
column4: Freshmore marks the start of every SUTD journey, equipping students with foundational skills for success.

column3: What are the components of the SUTD undergraduate curriculum?
column4: The SUTD undergraduate curriculum consists of a mandatory core curriculum, a variable curriculum, and outside-the-classroom experiences.

column3: What opportunities are available during the Independent Activities Period (IAP)?
column4: During the IAP, students can explore their passions and engage in new pursuits beyond traditional learning.

column3: What is the grading system for the first term at SUTD?
column4: In the first term, all subjects are grade-free, with students receiving either a 'Pass' or 'No Record' grade.

column3: What is the role of minors in the SUTD curriculum?
column4: Minors allow students to broaden their learning and gain an edge in the workplace by studying areas outside their degree.

column3: What are the five undergraduate programmes offered at SUTD?
column4: SUTD offers five programmes: Architecture and Sustainable Design, Engineering Product Development, Computer Science and Design, Engineering Systems and Design, and Design and Artificial Intelligence.

column3: What is the purpose of the Freshmore term?
column4: The Freshmore term equips students with foundational skills and knowledge to thrive at SUTD, marking the start of their academic journey.

column3: How does the variable curriculum benefit SUTD students?
column4: The variable curriculum allows students to customize their education through diverse minors, specialisation tracks, and sector-focused opportunities.

column3: What is the grading system in the first term at SUTD?
column4: In the first term, all subjects are grade-free, with students receiving either a 'Pass' or 'No Record' grade.

column3: What is the Capstone project at SUTD?
column4: The Capstone project is a final year collaborative effort where students from different majors work together to tackle real-world challenges.

column3: What skills does the SUTD curriculum aim to develop?
column4: The SUTD curriculum aims to develop technical depth, human-centred skills, and critical thinking for professional practice.

column3: What is the Freshmore curriculum designed to do?
column4: The Freshmore curriculum equips students with foundational skills and prepares them for success at SUTD.

column3: What are the minor programmes at SUTD?
column4: Minor programmes allow students to broaden their learning by studying areas outside their main degree.

column3: What is the role of special programmes in the SUTD curriculum?
column4: Special programmes provide opportunities in areas like entrepreneurship and research, enhancing the educational experience.

column3: What are special programmes at SUTD?
column4: Special programmes allow students to explore areas like entrepreneurship, medicine, and research, but are competitive and limited in places.

column3: What is the focus of the Freshmore curriculum at SUTD?
column4: The Freshmore curriculum focuses on integrating Design with AI, providing comprehensive training in Design·AI skills across all three terms.

column3: What subjects are common to all Freshmore students?
column4: Common subjects include Science, Mathematics and Technology (SMT), Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences (HASS), and design courses.

column3: How are grades structured in Term 1 of the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: All subjects in Term 1 are grade-free (Pass/No record), allowing students to adjust to academic life without worrying about grades.

column3: What are the elective options available in Term 3?
column4: Students can choose any 2 electives from Design Computation, Designing Sustainable Energy Solutions, Freshmore Design Studio, and others.

column3: What is the purpose of the computational thinking courses?
column4: These courses aim to strengthen digital literacy and illustrate how AI concepts can be integrated across various subjects.

column3: What is emphasized in the Introduction to Human-Centred Design course?
column4: The course emphasizes empathy, ethics, and contextual understanding in designing products, systems, and services.

column3: What are the two versions of the Math course offered?
column4: The two versions are (E) focused on engineering and technology, and (S) focused on economics and social sciences.

column3: What is the significance of the interdisciplinary design projects?
column4: These projects enhance design thinking, critical inquiry, problem-solving, communication, and collaboration skills relevant to the industry.

column3: What subjects are included in Term 1 of the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: Term 1 includes Innovating with Design & AI 1, Introduction to Programming, Calculus, Sustainability: Science and System Thinking, and Introduction to Social Sciences or Global Humanities.

column3: What is the grading structure for subjects in Term 1?
column4: All subjects in Term 1 are grade-free, using a Pass/No record system.

column3: What computational thinking courses are offered in the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: The computational thinking courses include Introduction to Programming in Term 1, Algorithmic Thinking & Object-Oriented Programming in Term 2, and Introduction to Machine Learning in Term 3.

column3: What is the focus of the Design Computation course?
column4: The Design Computation course focuses on building computational and representational design capabilities, introducing foundational programming and generative AI concepts.

column3: What are the two versions of the Math course offered in Terms 2 and 3?
column4: The two versions are the (E) version, emphasizing engineering and technology, and the (S) version, focusing on economics and social sciences.

column3: What is the significance of hands-on projects in the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: Hands-on projects transform theory into action, enhancing skills in design thinking, critical inquiry, problem-solving, communication, and collaboration.

column3: What is emphasized in the Global Humanities course?
column4: The Global Humanities course emphasizes critical thinking through classic works of literature and philosophy, exploring humanity's dreams and societal challenges.

column3: What subjects are included in Term 2 of the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: Term 2 includes Innovating with Design & AI 2, Algorithmic Thinking & Object-Oriented Programming, Linear Algebra & Multivariable Calculus (E/S), and Physics Principles and Applications 1.

column3: What foundational subjects are included in the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: The foundational subjects include Science, Mathematics and Technology (SMT), Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences (HASS), and design.

column3: What is the focus of the Introduction to Programming course?
column4: The Introduction to Programming course aims to strengthen students' digital literacy and prepare them for a data-driven world.

column3: What are the two versions of the Math course offered in Term 2?
column4: The two versions are (E) focused on engineering and technology, and (S) focused on economics and social sciences.

column3: What is the focus of the Introduction to Human-Centred Design course?
column4: The course focuses on principles of human-centred design, emphasizing empathy, ethics, and contextual understanding.

column3: What is the focus of the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: The Freshmore curriculum emphasizes integrating Design with AI, providing comprehensive training in Design·AI skills while building foundational literacy in Science, Mathematics, and Humanities.

column3: What are the core subjects in Term 1 of the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: Core subjects in Term 1 include Innovating with Design & AI 1, Introduction to Programming, Calculus, Sustainability: Science and System Thinking, and Introduction to Social Sciences or Global Humanities.

column3: What elective courses can students choose in Term 3?
column4: Students can choose from eight electives in Term 3, including Design Computation, Introduction to Healthcare Technology, and Introduction to Human-Centred Design.

column3: What are the two versions of the Math course offered in Term 3?
column4: The two versions of the Math course in Term 3 are Introduction to Probability and Statistics (E) focused on engineering and (S) focused on social sciences.

column3: What are the core subjects in Term 2 of the Freshmore curriculum?
column4: Core subjects in Term 2 include Innovating with Design & AI 2, Algorithmic Thinking & Object-Oriented Programming, Linear Algebra & Multivariable Calculus, and Physics Principles and Applications 1.

column3: What is required of Freshmore undergraduates regarding housing from Academic Year 2026?
column4: Freshmore undergraduates are required to reside at student housing on campus during Terms 1 to 3.

column3: What is the purpose of residential living for Freshmore students?
column4: Residential living complements cohort-based learning and aims to foster a sense of community and ownership among students.

column3: When can Freshmore students apply for housing after Term 3?
column4: Freshmore students may apply for housing together with other undergraduates during scheduled application windows, typically in February each year.

column3: When will information about the housing application window be published?
column4: Information on the housing application window will be published on the Undergraduate housing page by early February.

column3: When will housing offers be sent to the AY2026 Freshmore cohort?
column4: Housing offers will be sent progressively from early June 2026 to students who have completed their OMEx.

column3: What must students do during the housing offer acceptance period?
column4: Students need to login to the housing portal to accept and confirm their housing offers and complete a short questionnaire.

column3: What will guide the housing allocation for Freshmore students?
column4: Housing allocation will be guided by the Undergraduate Housing Allocation Scheme.

column3: When will more information on the housing allocation scheme be shared?
column4: More information on the scheme will be shared with incoming Freshmores after the start of the September term.

column3: What type of room are Freshmore students assigned to?
column4: Freshmore students are paired in double rooms according to their assigned class/cluster.

column3: How are roommates matched in the hostel?
column4: Roommates are matched based on a lifestyle questionnaire completed during the housing acceptance process.

column3: What security measures are in place at the hostel?
column4: The hostel has a 24/7 on-site security team, regular patrols, CCTV monitoring, and controlled access to facilities.

column3: What amenities are available in the communal kitchen?
column4: The communal kitchen is equipped with induction cookers, a multifunction oven, and vending machines.

column3: Where can students do laundry in the hostel?
column4: Students can use the laundry room on level 1, which has washing machines and dryers on a pay-per-use basis.

column3: What recreational facilities are available in the hostel?
column4: The hostel includes recreational rooms, study and discussion rooms, and a lounge.

column3: Is there internet access in the hostel?
column4: Yes, the hostel provides LAN points and WIFI for residents.

column3: What is the purpose of live-in staff and student leaders?
column4: They help foster a culture of care and respect, and address residents' concerns with the University.

column3: What facilities are available on each floor of the hostel?
column4: Each floor has communal shower and bathroom facilities, and a mini pantry with a microwave, hot/cold water dispenser, and sink.

column3: What is included in the communal kitchen on level 1?
column4: The communal kitchen on level 1 is equipped with induction cookers, a multifunction oven, and vending machines.

column3: What amenities are available in the pantry on level 9?
column4: The pantry on level 9 has a 2-burner induction cooker, microwave, hot water dispenser, and vending machines.

column3: Where is the laundry room located?
column4: The laundry room is located on level 1.

column3: What role do live-in staff and student leaders play?
column4: Live-in staff and student leaders foster a culture of care and respect, addressing residents' concerns and providing assistance.
